hints.content: Start by understanding what a 'lucky number' is in this context. Typically, lucky numbers are defined by a specific property or sequence. Make sure you clarify what defines a lucky number in this problem.

Consider how you might generate lucky numbers. You may want to begin with a simple approach, such as iterating through numbers and checking if they meet the lucky criteria. Think about a basic loop structure.

Think about the efficiency of your approach. Generating lucky numbers one by one could be slow, especially for larger values of K. Consider whether there is a mathematical way to generate lucky numbers instead of checking each number sequentially.
Remember to think about edge cases. What happens if K is 1 or if K is very large? You should ensure your solution can handle these extremes without failing.
Consider using a list or a set to store the lucky numbers you generate. This will allow you to easily access the K-th lucky number once you have generated enough of them.
If you're generating lucky numbers in a sequence, think about how you can keep track of the count of lucky numbers found so far. You might want to maintain a counter variable as you generate them.

You may also want to think about the possibility of duplicates. If lucky numbers can repeat, how will you ensure that your list only contains unique values? Using a set instead of a list can help with this.

Once you have generated enough lucky numbers, accessing the K-th number will depend on how you have stored them. If you're using a list, remember that lists are zero-indexed in most programming languages.

Before finalizing your solution, consider the performance implications of your approach. If you're generating lucky numbers up to a very high K, you might need to optimize your generation method to avoid excessive computation time.
Finally, think about how you will return the K-th lucky number. Ensure that your function has the correct return type and format as specified in the problem statement.

questionNotes: K is a positive integer, and you need to find the K-th lucky number.
Lucky numbers may have specific properties that you need to identify.
Make sure your solution handles edge cases, such as K being 1 or very large.
Consider the uniqueness of lucky numbers and how to store them efficiently.
